newsitem.title: USA: AFL-CIO says to provide aid to striking Teamsters.
newsitem.headline: AFL-CIO says to provide aid to striking Teamsters.

text.p: The AFL-CIO labour federation announced on Tuesday that it would provide enough financial support to the Teamsters union to help it wage a long strike against United Parcel Service.

"Before the week is out we will have enough loan commitments from other unions large and small to finance the worker side of this confrontation for a long strike if that's what it takes," said John Sweeney, president of the huge U.S. labour federation that comprises 78 U.S. unions including the Teamsters.
Teamsters President Ron Carey said it was costing the union $10 million a week to pay benefits to members while they are on strike against the giant package delivery company.
Sweeney said the AFL-CIO was prepared to help the union finance "many, many weeks at $10 million a week" to continue the bitter strike, now in its ninth day.
Labour Secretary Alexis Herman spoke to UPS and the Teamsters separately on Monday but failed to get the two sides back to the bargaining table. UPS said no talks are scheduled Tuesday.
The Teamsters want UPS to convert thousands of part-time jobs into full-time. UPS has ruled this out and warned that the Teamsters will lose 15,000 jobs if the strike lasts two working weeks.
